sen.e: FUJIWARA no Narito (987 – date of death unknown) is a noble in the Heian period.

sen.e: He is a son of FUJIWARA no Moronaga (Southern House) of the Matanari clique of the Southern House of the Fujiwara clan.

sen.e: His sons include FUJIWARA no Nagamune and FUJIWARA no Nagaaki.

sen.j: 主殿頭、出雲守などを歴任後，永承5年（1050年）、陸奥守として下向。
sen.e: After having successively held posts such as Tonomo no kami (the director of the Imperial Palace Keeper's Bureau) and Izumo no kami (the governor of Izumo Province), he left the capital as Mutsu no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province) in 1050.

After occupying posts such as Tonomo no kami (the director of the Imperial Palace Keeper's Bureau) and Izumo no kami (the governor of Izumo Province), he left the capital to become the Mutsu no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province) in 1050.
sen.cmt: "having successively held" is a bit of an awkward phrase. I think it is better put as "after occupying.."
sen.e: After occupying posts such as Tonomo no kami (the director of the Imperial Palace Keeper's Bureau) and Izumo no kami (the governor of Izumo Province), he left the capital to become the Mutsu no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province) in 1050.

sen.j: 翌年の永承6年（1051年）、安倍氏 (奥州)が衣川の柵を越え勢力圏を拡大しようとしたため、陸奥守だった登任は、秋田城介平重成らと安倍氏を討伐しようするが、逆に鬼切部で大敗を喫し更迭された。
sen.e: The next year in 1051, since the Abe clan (Oshu Province) tried to expand his region of authority beyond Koromogawa River, Narito, who was the Mutsu no kami, tried to subjugate the Abe clan with others such as TAIRA no Shigenari, Akitajo no suke (provincial governor of Akita-jo Castle in Dewa Province); on the contraries, however, he suffers a crushing loss in Onikiribe (a geographical name) and was dismissed.

In the following year of 1051, the Abe clan (Oshu Province) tried to expand their region of authority beyond Koromogawa River; Narito, the Mutsu no kami, joined forces with TAIRA no Shigenari, Akitajo no suke (provincial governor of Akita-jo Castle in Dewa Province) and others in an attempt to control them, but suffered a crushing loss in Onikiribe (a place) and was replaced.

In the following year of 1051, the Abe clan (Oshu Province) tried to expand their region of authority beyond the Koromo-gawa River; Narito, the Mutsu no kami (Governor of Mutsu Province), joined forces with TAIRA no Shigenari, Akitajo no suke (provincial governor of Akita-jo Castle in Dewa Province) and others in an attempt to control them, but suffered a crushing loss in Onikiribe and was replaced.

sen.j: 当時の状況は後任の源頼義による上奏文に、「東夷蜂起シ郡県ヲ領シ以ッテ夷地トナシ、人民ヲ駆使シ蛮虜トナシ六カ郡中、国務ニ従ガワズ、皇威ヲ忘ルルガ如シ」とある。
sen.e: The situation at that time is described in a report to the throne as: "Toi hokishi gunkenwo ryoshimotte ichitonashi, jinminwo kushishi banryotonashi mukagunchu, kokumuni shitagawazu, koiwo wasururugagotoshi"(People in six districts in the East of Kyoto revolted like barbarians, stating that they own the territories and acting against the order of the throne) by MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, Narito's successor.

The situation at that time was described in a report to the throne as "People in six districts in the East of Kyoto revolted like barbarians, stating that they own the territories and acting against the order of the throne", by MINAMOTO no Yoriyoshi, Narito's successor.
sen.cmt: I think it is meaningless to include the whole of the Japanese phrase in romaji here. Surely, the translation on its own is OK.
